text.text: can a person with diabeits can donate blood

text: Yes, people with diabetes can donate blood. However, they must meet the same eligibility criteria as everyone else, such as being at least 18 years old and weighing at least 50 kg. text.text: what is the diet of a donar person

text: If you donate blood, we recommend a healthy iron-enriched diet. Women aged 18-45 are particularly susceptible to low iron because of menstruation and pregnancy so we recommend a short course of iron supplements each time after you give blood (but not plasma). text.text: how should be daily person routine for blood donation

text: There is no specific daily routine for blood donors. However, it is important to eat a healthy diet and get enough sleep in order to maintain a healthy blood count. It is also important to drink plenty of fluids before and after donating blood to help replace the fluids that are lost during the donation process.

text.text: can a person with high haemoglobin can donate blood

text: Yes, a person with high haemoglobin can donate blood. The acceptable haemoglobin ranges for female donors are 120–165 g/L and for male donors are 130–185g/L. Would you like to take the eligibility quiz to find out if you can donate blood, and start changing lives?
